comments.commentBody: It's time to relinquish the fantasy of amateur sports at major football and basketball universities and start paying the athletes, or at least acknowledge that they are paid.

Its the Al Capone takedown - you know the real infractions involving student athletes at Syracuse and the benefits they egregiously accrue (monetary and academic) are much more serious but these are harder to unequivocally prove, so you find fool-proof evidence of the lesser kind and make your case.

$8000 really?  I mean that's less than I earned in my summer jobs at college, certainly less than I earned working part time in food services and janitor in college.  Instead of worrying about pennies getting to players maybe it wouldn't be such a problem if the NCAA actually played a stupiend or salary out of the millions of dollars they lavish on coach salaries and paying their own administrators. Maybe "student athletes"  who have to spend 40-50 hrs a week playing traveling and practicing wouldn't be looking for side interhships.  Give me a break, the spectacle of richly paid NCAA officials blaming poor or middle class players for a getting a bare minimum wage or some minor economic benefits turns my stomach, makes me allot less likely to want to watch a game.

Just ban all college sports from TV and get it back in perspective. This is probably just the tip of the iceberg. Do we really need to waste money investigating at all the schools? If even Syracuse breaks the rule, then who else? It wouldn't be important at all except we put the industry on a pedestal.

Agreed, but many universities can and do have speech codes that students are expected to abide by.

Whether those speech codes are constitutional in a taxpayer-funded university is a question that SCOTUS may have to resolve.
This is the most nefarious "expose" I've ever read. Remind me never to take a ride for free.

There is one significant distinction that makes RAV v. St. Paul not decisive in regard to the facts involving SAE and the Oklahoma students who were expelled.

RAV involving an individual being charged under a criminal statute with criminal sanctions. No such charges have been made, and the action taken was a civil one. David Boren probably acted legally in taking that action, even though there was no fact finding hearing or findings of fact yielded before he acted.

It is a separate question, not decided in RAV, whether speech not chargeable as a criminal offense is also the type of speech that is immune from civil actions.
I'd like to know how many classes Carmelo Anthony attended. The guy can barely put together a coherent sentence.

Yawn. Another day, another NCAA scandal. As scandals go, this one doesn't seem as terrible as, for example, the Penn State molestation scandal.

I'm sure that nothing will happen to the staff of either program, although if I were Syracuse administration I would want to know why and how such "rogue actions" were permitted, or at least unnoticed, by the head coaches.

Jumanne:

The mental gymnastics people will go through to justify trampling on First Amendment rights is astonishing and sad.

Well said, Dan.  The most humorous part is it took the NCAA the better part of 8 years to find violations, and this is what they come up with.  I'm not condoning any violation of any rules, but come on!  Miami athletes received millions, Syracuse athletes received hundreds, yet the media chooses to try and absolutely destroy Boeheim.  The guy isn't perfect by any stretch, and he has rubbed the media the wrong way for 37 years, so now its their turn I guess.  Just seems slightly misguided....
The administration, the coaches, the boosters, but what about the players? Why is it that so many players are more than willing to break the rules, rules they know?

The real crime in this whole situation is that the NCAA is slandering men for feeding hungry college students while continuing to facilitate the profit-machine that generates millions for universities, coaches, conference officials and the NCAA itself on the backs of those same hungry college kids.

I have skin the game. I already pay more than my fair share in taxes, in addition to SSN and Medicare taxes for programs that are going to benefit me much less than the current generation of retirees. The question here is not about unimaginably wealthy people or unscrupulous organizations - that is a separate debate. The question here is why a dual income upper middle class household where the husband and wife work regular jobs (software engineers, etc.) have to pay for their own health insurance and someone else's. We are not super wealthy, and we pay 25% of our gross income in taxes. The problem with your argument is that it's not the wealthy who are getting penalized - it's the middle class.

The trouble with this article and the one on March 8 by William Rhoden is that they are both agenda driven. Mr. Rhoden has been against NCAA big time athletics for a long time. The title of this article is so slanted it violates journalistic standards. If you read the NCAA report you will find that Syracuse did technically violate policies but the policies are not questioned. If I were an NCAA coach I would look for a professional job because it seems inconceivable that I could always avoid some violations. I doubt that any program could stand up to this level of scrutiny. Giving a student a car ride? Playing in a charity game? And with regard to Student One in the report this was clearly a troubled young man who bonded with someone with enough experience to help him. But in the eyes of the NCAA this was collusion of the worst sort. If my child was a student Most commentators in this forum have come to the same conclusion.
These two writers and the NY Times do not like collegiate athletics as they exist today but ratings, ticket sales and the great number of aspiring athletes tell a different story. As for Student 1 in the report it sounds to me like a lot of people were trying to help a troubled young man

The government.... The OU is not the government

The students accept a certain behavior code when they enroll. They violated it.

They have the option the argue their case as the article stated.

Good to see that there are always some good people standing up for blatant racists.

Nice!!
Let me get this right.  The utterly corrupt NC a a has determined Syracuse is corrupt. Ironic,  seems they have turned their corruption into an money making art form

Jumanne:

Do you believe that any employee uttering these words or other offensive words *in privacy* should face termination if caught?

So, Jeff Cornish spent money unwisely and maybe unethically as a booster for Syracuse some years ago. But now, he's a project manager at NYSDOT? What if he's applying the same ethics at NYSDOT that he did as a booster for Syracuse? He could be doing much more damage than the $8,000 he spent in Syracuse by "boosting" for contractors.

Still, I suppose we have to err on the side of assuming his sense of ethics has changed.

Time to come clean, Hayden, as you are completely misrepresenting the situation regarding Steven Salatia. His remarks were clearly anti-Israel, not anti-Jewish or anti-Semitic. He spoke in opposition to the policies of the Israeli government and those settlers illegally occupying even more land in the West Bank.

If you are part of the misguided few who continue to conflate such criticisms of Israel government policy with anti-Jewish sentiments than you will remain confused, misguided and in two words: Dead Wrong.

Conflating anti-Israeli governmental policy with anti-Jewish sentiments is a shameful ploy that has lost any claim to relevance. The world at large is on to the scam and are pushing back against you more and more every day.

And no Republican criticized these actions?????

And besides, none of the Democratic scalawags that you mentioned wrote such an amateurish letter that seemed a lot like schoolyard trash talk. Isn't there any Senator among the 47 who can wield a red pen?

Let me translate for you.

Liberal bigotry is real and it isn’t being confronted by the media. It’s being encouraged. You don’t have to be a conservative, straight white male to be a racist.

One form of racism cannot be defeated by another. If we fight fire with fire the house is going to burn down.

The NCAA is the most hypocritical institution in America. Pro leagues at least pay the players and don't pretend to be anything other than money-making entities.

The NCAA, though, is part of a system that dangles riches and fame before the eyes of poor kids, convincing them that basketball is their way out, exploits them to earn millions of dollars and then ejects them into the streets without an education or a penny -- all the while calling them "student athletes".

It's the most reprehensible and morally dishonest institution in America. I haven't watched college basketball for 20 years. I don't care about who wins or loses. You shouldn't either.

Bumpercar - Syracuse University, 1980

Well over a hundred years ago Ivy League schools and small liberal arts colleges put athletics in their proper role:  Not really all that important.  We are in the education business, not the business of winning national championships.  The rest of the country should follow their lead.  It won't but it should.

Ironic that it took a racist chant, secretly recorded on the bus that took those formal-costumed frat boys and their dates to the Frat Founders Day 'official' shindig, to get Oklahoma's administration to wake up. Then again, students at such football-and-frat schools typically know better than to complain about hazing. (Considering how many powerful, rich alumni tend to have been 'Greeks', that would probably do their career prospects almost as much good as a murder rap.) So the frats got away with everything, as long as they could prevent pledges from winding up in the ER or the morgue, until this one got caught out at some very 'politically incorrect' (not to mention just plain nauseatingly racist) behaviour.
Don't expect radical changes from this little episode. One frat's out and another one will eventually come in, perhaps a 'minority' one (Complete with all the traditional hazing, money-grubbing conformity and enforced groupthink typical of the lot of them, members' skin pigmentation variations notwithstanding.) The system will endure, doing what it does best - making sure that only the correctly conditioned people get a shot at leadership roles in the worlds of business and government. As the rest of us, the outsider peasantry, merely endure.
